pageData.text: In this virtual investigation, you will learn about the tests and stains used to examine microbial organisms. You will then identify one or more unknown microorganisms based on the test result images provided. These images are actual results obtained by researchers in a laboratory and may not reflect expected results.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText: Activity – 45 minutes per unknown microbe

pageData.text: Follow your instructor’s directions as to which microbe(s) to identify.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text: There are no materials required for this investigation.

In 2021, after months of trying to figure out what was causing a mysterious outbreak, the CDC determined that an aromatherapy spray was to blame. Four patients in four different states all suffered from a rare bacterial disease called melioidosis. Unfortunately, two of the patients died from the disease. Melioidosis is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, and is associated with a wide range of symptoms that are often misdiagnosed as the flu or the common cold.

In the United States, there are only about 12 confirmed cases of melioidosis annually. B. pseudomallei is naturally found in South and Southeast Asia and northern Australia. Most cases worldwide are in people who live in these regions or have traveled there. The contaminated spray, “Better Homes & Gardens Lavender & Chamomile Essential Oil Infused Aromatherapy Room Spray with Gemstones,” was found in the home of a Georgia resident who became ill with melioidosis. The genetic fingerprint of the bacteria that caused melioidosis in the four patients was similar to that of strains that are usually found in South Asia. Turns out, the spray was made in India<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1CDC. (2021). Aromatherapy spray tests positive for deadly bacteria. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2021/p1022-aromatherapy-bacteria.html

pageData.text: We are surrounded by microorganisms. Most of them are harmless, but occasionally there are microbes that can cause disease. Disease-causing microorganisms are called . There are approximately 1,400 known species of human pathogens, however this makes up only a tiny fraction of the estimated one trillion microbial species on the planet. The microbes that make us sick often receive the bulk of the attention, likely because they make their presence known by triggering our immune systems. Understanding what is making us ill is the first step to effectively treating the cause of the condition; and because we cannot see these organisms with the unaided eye, we use tools and biochemical tests to decipher the microbial world. In this investigation, you will be taken through a series of biochemical tests to narrow down and identify unknown microbes from a list of possible organisms.

To help identify what an organism is, a series of microscopic and biochemical tests can be performed. Many of these tests pre-date the computer age and were created before there were accurate ways to measure subtle color changes digitally. For example, one individual may interpret a pink color as red pink, while another may see it as more of an orange-pink.

To help maintain objectivity between the scientists interpreting such results, most were set up with yes or no questions. For example, “can the organism metabolize sugar?” This is simply a yes or no question: it does not tell us anything about how the organism uses glucose, only that it can. These yes-or-no questions can be organized into a and can be used as a road map for identifying a specific microbe from a list of possibilities.

For example, the first question in the you will use in this investigation is:
  1. Does the microbe have a coccus shape?
    1. Yes... Go to Question 2.
    2. No... Go to Question 5.

pageData.text: Bacteria, like other microorganisms, require nutrients to grow and reproduce. In a laboratory setting, bacteria are grown on food sources that contain different components. Those food sources are called <button class='glossary-text'>media</button>. Media can be a general nutrient source that lets most organisms grow or it can be a formulation of specialized nutrients that can be used to differentiate between, or select for, specific microorganisms.

The way an organism grows in different types of media can offer clues about the microbe as well. For instance, media can come in a solid state (like a Petri dish), as a broth, or as a <button class='glossary-text'>semi-solid</button> (like gelatin). Some organisms will grow more easily in the broth than on the Petri dish medium or vice versa, which can indicate characteristics about what that organism needs from its environment. <button class='glossary-text'>Agar</button> is a gelatinous thickening agent obtained from seaweed and is used to make broth media into semi-solids, plates, and slant cultures.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Examples of broth, plate, and semi-solid bacterial growth media.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Examples of broth, plate, and semi-solid bacterial growth media.

pageData.text: When an organism requires something to survive it is called an <button class='glossary-text'>obligate</button> organism for that specific environmental condition. The most common environmental requirement is oxygen, which can be observed in a <button class='glossary-text'>broth tube</button>. If a microbe can only grow on the surface of a broth tube, it requires oxygen. Figure 2 shows an example of an obligate anaerobe growing on the surface of broth medium where the oxygen concentration is greatest. Oxygen levels decrease deeper into the medium.

If an organism grows at the bottom of the tube, that indicates a preference for less oxygen, indicating the bacteria have metabolic pathways that allow metabolism to take place in the absence of oxygen. When an organism can only survive without oxygen, it is an obligate anaerobe. None of the bacteria in this investigation are obligate anaerobes. Creating an oxygen-free environment is difficult in a laboratory setting and makes studying obligate anaerobes challenging. The most common anaerobe studied is classified as a facultative anaerobe, meaning it can perform aerobic respiration when oxygen is present but can perform fermentation metabolism when oxygen is absent. These organisms will grow well in either oxygen-rich or oxygen-depleted environments.

pageData.disc: Figure 2: A tube of broth medium, on the surface of which is bacterial growth.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A tube of broth medium, on the surface of which is bacterial growth.

pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>streak plate</button> is a way to isolate organisms from a mixture. To obtain a pure culture of a single organism, you need to make sure that you have only that specific organism. Microbes in the environment, however, are not isolated. A streak plate uses dilution to isolate one organism from many. While it is nearly impossible to determine what type of bacteria is growing only by looking at how it grows, some families of bacteria do have characteristics that are visible when cultured in this manner. For example, the cultures in Figure 3 are all on the same type of <button class='glossary-text'>media</button>, but the sizes, shapes, and colors of their colonies are very different. A <button class='glossary-text'>colony</button> is a group of bacteria descended from a single cell.

pageData.disc: Figure 3: 4 different streak plates. Each plate has bacterial colonies with a different shape and color.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: 4 different streak plates. Each plate has bacterial colonies with a different shape and color.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Broth tubes</button> are commonly used in biochemical assays because the composition of the <button class='glossary-text'>media</button> is known and can be adjusted. An uninoculated tube of broth medium is first sterilized to make sure there are no other bacteria growing, then an organism is transferred to the tube in a process called <button class='glossary-text'>inoculation</button>. The inoculated tube is then grown for a certain amount of time at a certain temperature. If bacteria growth occurs, the broth will become cloudy or opaque. This cloudiness is called <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button>. In general, the more turbid a broth tube, the more bacterial growth is present. When other chemicals are added, changes in pH, enzyme activity, or other chemical reactions can be detected (Figure 4). Broth tubes are a highly versatile medium used to identify organisms.

are a mix of broth and that does not solidify completely. Semi-solids can be used for numerous assays, but the most common is . Bacteria that can propel themselves can move through the semi-solid matrix. Color indicators can be added to make visualization easier. Semi-solids are usually inoculated by stab method, meaning bacteria are placed on an inoculation needle, which is stabbed down into the medium. This can also be used to determine the oxygen requirements of an organism because oxygen concentrations are highest near the semi-solid's surface, like in a broth tube.

pageData.disc: Figure 4: 4 different biochemical tests performed in inoculated broth tubes - pH, urea, indole and glucose - next to a control tube with 24 hour growth.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: 4 different biochemical tests performed in inoculated broth tubes - pH, urea, indole and glucose - next to a control tube with 24 hour growth.

pageData.text: Microorganisms are too small to be seen with the unaided eye. Even when viewed under a microscope at 1000X magnification, they can still be difficult to see. To enhance visualization, staining procedures are used to either highlight a specific attribute or to give the organisms more contrast.

A staining procedure that uses only one stain is called a . A simple stain that interacts with the bacteria themselves is called a . This type of stain can be used to determine the shape of the cell (also called its ), as well as the relative size and the arrangement of the cells. Chemically, a simple stain works by a charge interaction between the stain and the cell. Bacteria cells have a negative charge on their outer surface. Remember, opposite charges attract, so a positively charged stain will interact with the negatively charged bacterial surface. Three common direct simple stains include methylene blue, crystal violet, and safranin. Because these stains provide the positive charge, they are chemically going to give up a hydroxide ion (OH-) or accept a hydrogen ion (H+), and therefore act as bases.

Simple stains are fast, easy stains used to determine the shape of a bacterial microorganism. Some common shapes of bacteria are <button class='glossary-text'>coccus</button> (spherical), <button class='glossary-text'>bacillus</button> (rod), and <button class='glossary-text'>spirillum</button> (spiral) (Figure 5). Shape is an important classification tool and is often one of the first assays used to identify an organism. To prepare a simple stain, a small amount of culture is “fixed” to the slide. <button class='glossary-text'>Fixing</button> the specimen to the slide helps adhere it to the slide and also chemically changes the enzymes in the cell through a process called denaturation. Denaturing is done using heat or alcohol and makes the enzymes in a cell inactive.

pageData.disc: Figure 5: Examples of spherical, rod, and curved shapes of bacteria
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Examples of spherical, rod, and curved shapes of bacteria

pageData.text: Another strategy to stain the organism is to stain the background and leave the organism unstained. Bacteria are negatively charged on the surface. An acidic dye is a negatively charged dye, which chemically means the dye will donate a hydrogen ion. A negatively charged bacteria cell will repel a negatively charged dye; the dye will instead stick to the glass slide, leaving a cleared area where the cell is located.

A , like a direct basic stain, can be used to determine the , size, and arrangement of microorganisms. Negative stains are arguably better at determining morphology and arrangement because the slide preparation does not involve a fixation step, which if used in direct to adhere the sample to the slide. In a negative stain, a sample is mixed directly with the dye and spread across the slide. Just as bacteria can come in many shapes, they can also have many configurations ().

is a technique which helps differentiate between Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. The technique uses a series of chemical means to penetrate the cell wall of a bacterium. Depending upon the composition of the cell wall, the bacterium will retain or repel the different stains. Being able to tell a Gram-positive organism from a Gram-negative one is important clinically because it can help determine which type of antibiotics will be effective, as a large group of antibiotics mechanistically work by disrupting microbial cell walls. Gram-positive organisms have a thick layer of peptidoglycan and a second outer cell membrane (Figure 6).

pageData.disc: Figure 6: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.text: The first stain used is crystal violet, which is a basic stain. This works as a for both Gram-positive and Gram-negative cells. The next step is to add Gram’s iodine, which acts as a , meaning it facilitates fixation between the crystal violet and the peptidoglycan in the cell wall as it binds to the crystal violet and forms a larger crystal violet-iodine complex. Next, a decolorizer, ethyl alcohol, is applied. In the Gram-positive cells, the crystal violet-iodine complex is trapped in the thick peptidoglycan, while in the Gram-negative cells, the complex remains on the outside of the outer membrane and will be washed away. The positive cells retain color, and the negative cells lose it. In the last step, another basic stain, safranin, is added. Safranin is a reddish/orange dye that will stain the Gram-negative cells pink or red. It will also stain the Gram-positive cells, but is not strong enough to overpower the darker, previously applied stains, so these cells remain purple. Figure 7 summarizes the steps of a ; Figure 8 shows an example of Gram-stained bacteria under a microscope.

image.desc: Figure 7: Steps in the Gram-staining technique
image.altText: Figure 7: Steps in the Gram-staining technique

image.desc: Figure 8: A differential stain distinguishes Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria
image.altText: Figure 8: A differential stain distinguishes Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.text: Bacteria often secrete chemicals that form a viscous coat on their surfaces. If it has a smooth round or oval shape, it is called a <button class='glossary-text'>capsule</button>; if it has more of an irregular shape, it is called a slime layer. Most of the capsule or slime layer will be made of polysaccharides, which are water soluble and neutrally charged. <button class='glossary-text'>Direct stains</button> work by interacting with a negatively charged bacterial surface. Because the capsule is more neutral, a direct stain will not adhere to it.

To see the capsule, first a <button class='glossary-text'>negative stain</button> is applied to stain the background, followed by a direct stain to show the bacteria inside the capsule (Figure 9). Capsules are considered a <button class='glossary-text'>virulence factor</button> for bacteria, meaning it can enhance a bacterium’s ability to cause a disease by protecting it from an immune response. They can also protect bacteria from environmental conditions, such as desiccation (drying out).

pageData.disc: Figure 9: Micrograph of several stained rod-shaped bacterial cells, each surrounded by a clear colorless halo representing a capsule. One capsule is indicated with an arrow.
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Micrograph of several stained rod-shaped bacterial cells, each surrounded by a clear colorless halo representing a capsule. One capsule is indicated with an arrow.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Endospores</button> are a way that some species of bacteria are able to respond to and survive external stressors, such as harsh chemical and environmental changes. Endospores are in an inactive state in which metabolism is severely limited. They form when there is an absence of water or essential nutrients. When endospores form inside a cell, the surrounding material (the old cell) disintegrates. Endospores can remain dormant for extended periods, and when conditions are ideal, they can germinate into vegetative cells that are metabolically active.

The resistance of endospores to harsh conditions also makes them resistant to staining. Endospore staining requires harsher techniques to get the dye to penetrate the spores. Once slides are prepared, the dye is steamed into the organism. This dye is usually a green dye called malachite green. Then the slide is counterstained with a basic stain, safranin, to show the vegetative cells. Figure 10 shows stained endospores (green) and vegetative cells (red) under a microscope.

Two groups of bacteria that are known to form endospores are Clostridium and . In this case, Bacillus refers to the bacterial genus and not the shape of the bacteria, although these bacteria are bacillus shaped. In an endospore stain, some cells will have spores, some will be forming spores, and some will not be forming spores. Cultures must be in a distressed state for spores to be visible as spores are a survival mechanism.

pageData.disc: Figure 10: An illustration and a micrograph showing stained vegetative cells and endospores. Each image shows rod-shaped vegetative cells and circular endospores.
pageData.altText: Figure 10: An illustration and a micrograph showing stained vegetative cells and endospores. Each image shows rod-shaped vegetative cells and circular endospores.

pageData.text: For organisms that do not stain well with simple or , specifically those with waxy cell walls in the genus Mycobacterium, an can be used. The smear is first stained with carbol fuchsin. This solubilizes the outer waxy, lipid layer. Adding heat then allows the carbol fuchsin to penetrate deeper into the cell and the cell will appear red. The smear is decolorized with acid alcohol, a mixture of 95% alcohol and 3% hydrochloric acid. Acid-fast cells will resist decolorization due to the large amount of lipid (waxy) outer layer. Non-acid-fast organisms will easily decolorize and no longer be visible. The smear is then counterstained with methylene blue. Figure 11 shows these stained cells under a microscope: acid-fast-positive cells will be pink (B), and acid-fast-negative cells will be dark blue/purple (A). Be careful not to mix up and acid-fast staining results as their positive and negative colorations are opposite of one another.

pageData.disc: Figure 11: A micrograph of two different bacteria species stained with acid-fast staining. One type of bacteria, labeled A, are circular and purple. The other type of bacteria, labeled B, are rod shaped and pink.
pageData.altText: Figure 11: A micrograph of two different bacteria species stained with acid-fast staining. One type of bacteria, labeled A, are circular and purple. The other type of bacteria, labeled B, are rod shaped and pink.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements is true about Gram stain and acid-fast stain?

options.text: Both stains differentiate based on cell wall composition.
Gram stain uses more dyes than acid-fast stain.
Gram stain highlights bacterial capsules; acid-fast stain highlights endospores.
Gram-positive cells appear pink; acid-fast-positive cells appear purple.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Gram stain differentiates based on the overall structure, especially the peptidoglycan content, of bacterial cell walls. Acid-fast stain differentiates the genus Mycobacterium, which has waxy cell walls, from all other bacteria.

pageData.question: Which of the following interpretations of Gram stain and acid-fast stain is correct?

options.text: Gram-positive cells appear purple; acid-fast positive cells appear pink.
Gram-positive and acid-fast positive cells are both purple.
Gram-positive cells appear pink; acid-fast positive cells appear purple.
Gram-positive and acid-fast positive cells are both pink.
Gram-positive cells appear clear; acid-fast positive cells appear pink.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Although mixed cultures stained with either Gram stain or acid-fast stain will result in pink and purple cells, Gram-positive cells appear purple whereas acid-fast positive cells appear pink.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Gram staining differentiates Gram-negative bacteria and Gram-positive bacteria based on the composition of the cell walls. Gram-positive bacteria appear purple and Gram-negative bacteria appear pink. Acid-fast staining differentiates acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast bacteria based on the mycolic acid content in the cell wall, specifically those in the Mycobacterium genus. Carbol fuchsin is the primary stain in the acid-fast staining technique. An acid-alcohol solution is then applied as the decolorizing agent. A secondary counterstain, methylene blue, is then applied. The waxy, acid-fast cells retain the carbol fuchsin even after a decolorizing agent and appear pinkish red and the non–acid-fast cells will be stained dark blue/purple.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Gram staining differentiates Gram-negative bacteria and Gram-positive bacteria based on the composition of the cell walls. Gram-positive bacteria appear purple and Gram-negative bacteria appear pink. Acid-fast staining differentiates acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast bacteria based on the mycolic acid content in the cell wall, specifically those in the Mycobacterium genus. Carbol fuchsin is the primary stain in the acid-fast staining technique. An acid-alcohol solution is then applied as the decolorizing agent. A secondary counterstain, methylene blue, is then applied. The waxy, acid-fast cells retain the carbol fuchsin even after a decolorizing agent and appear pinkish red and the non–acid-fast cells will be stained dark blue/purple.

pageData.text: Phenol red broth is a general-purpose broth that contains peptone, phenol red (a pH indicator), a single carbohydrate source, and a <button class='glossary-text'>Durham tube</button>. A Durham tube is a smaller test tube upside down inside the main test tube; it is used to collect gas produced by microorganisms as they metabolize sugars. Common sugar sources include dextrose, sucrose, lactose, maltose, and mannitol. Each tube will contain only one of these carbohydrates.

This test shows two types of results. The first is whether the organism can metabolize the sugar source in the medium. This is done by observing the pH of the medium via a pH indicator color change. If an organism can utilize the carbohydrate in the medium, an acid byproduct is created, which turns the medium yellow. If the organism cannot metabolize the carbohydrate, the peptone in the medium is metabolized instead and the byproduct is ammonia, which raises the pH of the medium and turns it fuschia (pinkish red).

The second type of test result is whether the organism produced a gas, which is indicated by the presence of a bubble in the Durham tube. The two types of test results (sugar metabolism and gas formation) are read independently of each other, so it is possible for a microorganism to test positive in one aspect and negative in the other. Figure 12 shows an uninoculated phenol red <button class='glossary-text'>broth tube</button> with a Durham tube in place (left) compared to a completed test with positive results for both sugar metabolism and gas formation (right).

pageData.disc: Figure 12: A negative control phenol red broth tube on the left, and a positive control phenol red broth tube on the right. Each tube has a small upside down Durham tube placed at the bottom of the tube. The negative control has red broth with no bubbles inside its Durham tube. The positive control has yellow broth, which indicates carbohydrate source metabolism, and a gas bubble captured inside its Durham tube.
pageData.altText: Figure 12: A negative control phenol red broth tube on the left, and a positive control phenol red broth tube on the right. Each tube has a small upside down Durham tube placed at the bottom of the tube. The negative control has red broth with no bubbles inside its Durham tube. The positive control has yellow broth, which indicates carbohydrate source metabolism, and a gas bubble captured inside its Durham tube.

pageData.text: This assay utilizes one broth to perform two tests. Bacteria utilize dextrose and glucose metabolically to make pyruvate in different ways. Some of the metabolic pathways produce acidic byproducts, which are unstable and convert to neutral compounds. In the butylene glycol pathway, acetoin and d2,3-butanediol are produced and are neutral end products. In the mixed acid pathway, acid byproducts such as lactic acid, acetic acid, and formic acid and produced, which are stable in these acid forms.

The methyl red (MR) test is performed by adding the methyl red pH indicator to an inoculated tube of <button class='glossary-text'>MR-VP broth</button>. If the organism uses the mixed acid pathway, the methyl red indicator will stay red. Methyl red is yellow at pH 6.2 and red at pH 4.4 or below. Be careful not to confuse this with phenol red, which turns yellow below a pH of 6.8.

If the organism utilizes the butylene glycol pathway, the byproduct acetoin which will become oxidized by potassium hydroxide (KOH) in the Voges-Proskauer (VP) reagents when they are added to the medium. Acetoin oxidizes to diacetyl, which will react to produce a red color. A red is a positive result for the VP test; if the reagents produce a copper color, the result is negative.

pageData.disc: Figure 13: Five different inoculated MRVP broth tubes. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second tube shows a positive result after the addition of methyl red as a sustained red color. The third tube shows a negative result after the addition of methyl red as a yellow color change. The fourth tube shows a positive result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a red color. The fifth tube shows a negative result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a copper color change.
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Five different inoculated MRVP broth tubes. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second tube shows a positive result after the addition of methyl red as a sustained red color. The third tube shows a negative result after the addition of methyl red as a yellow color change. The fourth tube shows a positive result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a red color. The fifth tube shows a negative result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a copper color change.

pageData.text: This assay looks at the ability of the bacteria to produce a nitrate reductase enzyme, which will hydrolyze nitrate (NO<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>) into nitrite (NO<sub class='bodysubscript'>2</sub>). Two reagents are added to a culture and if a color change occurs, it is positive for nitrate. If no color change is observed, it means the organism can either not reduce nitrate or the organism denitrifies the nitrate to make ammonia or molecular nitrogen.

To conclusively determine the results of a negative <button class='glossary-text'>nitrate reduction test</button>, an additional step is performed. A small amount of zinc powder is added. If the tube turns red or pink after this addition it means unreduced nitrate is present and the test result is indeed negative. If the tube does not turn red after zinc is added, then the test result is positive and indicates denitrification took place.

pageData.disc: Figure 14: Six different inoculated broth tubes demonstrating nitrate reduction test results. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second and third tubes show positive results as red and pink color changes, respectively. The fourth tube shows an inconclusive result as a yellow color change. The fifth tube shows a negative result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as no color change. The sixth tube shows a positive result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as a red color change.
pageData.altText: Figure 14: Six different inoculated broth tubes demonstrating nitrate reduction test results. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second and third tubes show positive results as red and pink color changes, respectively. The fourth tube shows an inconclusive result as a yellow color change. The fifth tube shows a negative result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as no color change. The sixth tube shows a positive result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as a red color change.

pageData.text: To perform this test, the <button class='glossary-text'>semi-solid</button> <button class='glossary-text'>SIM agar</button> is inoculated with a microbial culture using a needle stab. Cultures are incubated for 48 hours before Kovac’s reagent is added to the medium and observations are made.

This assay looks at three tests:
  • (S) Sulfur reduction through cysteine desulfurase: If bacteria produce cysteine desulfurase, amino acids with sulfur atoms are broken down into pyruvate, ammonia, and hydrogen sulfide. Iron will react with hydrogen sulfide and make a black precipitate (Figure 15, top).
  • (I) Indole production through tryptophanase: If bacteria can make tryptophanase, it can use the amino acid tryptophan as a carbon source. A byproduct of this is indole, which is detected by Kovac’s reagent as it turns a pink or red color (Figure 15, middle).
  • (M) is present when growth away from the stab line is observed. In a semi-solid medium, the gelatinous consistency allows motile microbes to spread away from the center (Figure 15, bottom). If bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide, and therefore a black precipitate, the motility test is inconclusive as motility is not observable through the precipitate.

pageData.disc: Figure 15: Three test tubes of sulfur indole motility agar inoculated with bacteria. The first tube has a precipitate in the bottom. The second tube has a thin top layer that changed color after Kovac's reagent was added. The third tube has cloudiness away from the central stab of the inoculating needle.
pageData.altText: Figure 15: Three test tubes of sulfur indole motility agar inoculated with bacteria. The first tube has a precipitate in the bottom. The second tube has a thin top layer that changed color after Kovac's reagent was added. The third tube has cloudiness away from the central stab of the inoculating needle.

pageData.text: This test assesses an organism’s ability to use citrate as a carbon source. <button class='glossary-text'>Simmons citrate agar</button> uses sodium citrate as the carbon source, ammonium dihydrogen phosphate as the nitrogen source, nutrients, and the pH indicator bromothymol blue. It is used primarily to identify Enterobacteriaceae, which are primarily found in the intestinal tract.

At pH 7.5 and above, bromothymol blue turns royal blue. At neutral pH it is green. If the <button class='glossary-text'>media</button> turns blue, the organism is citrate positive (Figure 16, right). Some organisms may grow on the surface but not produce a color change. Slants are incubated at 37° C and monitored every 24 hours for 7 days. Organisms that degrade the citrate in the <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> must also use ammonium salts, which produces ammonia and increases the pH, leading to the color change. This media is mainly used for differentiating Gram-negative bacteria.

pageData.disc: Figure 16: Two culture tubes containing inoculated slants of solid simmons citrate agar. The first tube shows a negative result with green medium. The second tube shows a positive result with blue medium.
pageData.altText: Figure 16: Two culture tubes containing inoculated slants of solid simmons citrate agar. The first tube shows a negative result with green medium. The second tube shows a positive result with blue medium.

pageData.text: This test determines whether an organism can break down that occurs due to the presence of the enzyme urease. Urea is an end byproduct of amino acid (protein) metabolism and is a compound made up of a carbonyl group and two amines. When urea is split by hydrolysis, it produces ammonia and carbon dioxide. Ammonia causes the pH of the medium to become more alkaline and the phenol red pH indicator in the medium changes from light orange (pH 6.8) to magenta pink (pH 8.1) as shown in Figure 17. Weakly positive organisms may take several days, and negative organisms will not show a color change. Broth or can be used for this assay. The broth or agar is inoculated and grown at 37° C for 48 hours to 7 days.

pageData.disc: Figure 17: Two test tubes filled with inoculated broth media containing a pH indicator and urea. The first tube shows a negative result with a light orange color change. The second tube shows a positive result with a magenta pink color change.
pageData.altText: Figure 17: Two test tubes filled with inoculated broth media containing a pH indicator and urea. The first tube shows a negative result with a light orange color change. The second tube shows a positive result with a magenta pink color change.

pageData.text: Milk contains the protein casein, the sugar lactose, various vitamins, minerals, and water, thus making it a great medium for growing microorganisms. The addition of litmus, a pH indicator, allows for differentiation as bacterial species metabolize milk components differently. When lactose is fermented, the <button class='glossary-text'>litmus milk</button> turns pink as a result of acid fermentation. If enough acid is produced, the proteins (casein) will coagulate, solidifying the milk. If bacteria hydrolyze the casein, it will become straw colored.

Litmus milk test results include:
  • White: litmus was reduced and appears clear.
  • Darker pink/red: lactose was fermented, and the medium is acidic.
  • Bluish: lactose was NOT fermented, and the medium is basic.
  • Brown ring: casein protein was broken down by proteolysis.
  • Coagulation: curds formed, which formation may occur with or without gas.
There are quite a few metabolic processes that can be observed using litmus milk, which can make interpreting the results complex. Figure 18 shows some examples of these results.

pageData.disc: Figure 18: Seven culture tubes containing litmus milk media. The first tube is uninoculated and has a milky pink color. The six other culture tubes are inoculated and show various color changes after 7 days of incubation.
pageData.altText: Figure 18: Seven culture tubes containing litmus milk media. The first tube is uninoculated and has a milky pink color. The six other culture tubes are inoculated and show various color changes after 7 days of incubation.

pageData.text: This <button class='glossary-text'>media</button> allows differentiation between organisms that make an exogenous enzyme named gelatinase and those that do not. Gelatin is a protein that is derived from collagen. Gelatin is too large to enter the cell, so if the enzyme can break down gelatin, then gelatinase must be excreted from the cell.

This test is performed by incubating an organism in a and then cooling it. As gelatin is broken down, it is converted into smaller subunits and takes on a liquid form. If gelatin is present and not degraded, when it is cooled in the refrigerator it will solidify like gelatin made at home. If the gelatin is degraded by gelatinase, then it will not solidify when cooled. The tubes are held at an angle to observe the medium’s ability to hold its shape: a negative result in which gelatin is present will hold its shape (Figure 19, top), while a positive result in which gelatin is broken down will start to spill down the tube as it is tilted (Figure 19, bottom).

pageData.disc: Figure 19: Two culture tubes containing inoculated semi-solid media. The first tube shows a negative result with unmoving semi-solid media. The second tube shows a positive result with moving, liquified semi-solid media.
pageData.altText: Figure 19: Two culture tubes containing inoculated semi-solid media. The first tube shows a negative result with unmoving semi-solid media. The second tube shows a positive result with moving, liquified semi-solid media.

pageData.question: Which of the following tests does NOT rely on a color change?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Nutrient gelatin tests evaluate whether bacteria can break down gelatin using gelatinase: a positive result will show the gelatin medium loses its shape in the culture tube when it is tilted.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Phenol red fermentation tests utilize phenol red broth, which is a general-purpose broth that contains peptone, phenol red (a pH indicator), and a single carbohydrate source, as well as a Durham tube. This test evaluates both sugar metabolism and gas formation. The Methyl Red Voges-Proskauer (MRVP) assay utilizes one broth to perform two tests to determine which pyruvate-metabolizing pathway is used. The nitrate reduction test looks at the ability of the bacteria to produce a nitrate reductase enzyme, which will hydrolyze nitrate (NO3) into nitrite (NO2). The Sulfur Indole Motility (SIM) assay uses Kovac’s reagent looks at three tests - sulfur reduction through cysteine desulfurase, indole production through tryptophanase, and motility. Simmons citrate agar assesses an organism’s ability to use citrate as a carbon source. The urea test determines whether an organism can break down urea that occurs due to the presence of the enzyme urease. Tests using litmus milk differentiate between bacterial species based on how they metabolize milk components. Using nutrient gelatin as a medium allows differentiation between organisms that make an exogenous enzyme named gelatinase and those that do not.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Phenol red fermentation tests utilize phenol red broth, which is a general-purpose broth that contains peptone, phenol red (a pH indicator), and a single carbohydrate source, as well as a Durham tube. This test evaluates both sugar metabolism and gas formation. The Methyl Red Voges-Proskauer (MRVP) assay utilizes one broth to perform two tests to determine which pyruvate-metabolizing pathway is used. The nitrate reduction test looks at the ability of the bacteria to produce a nitrate reductase enzyme, which will hydrolyze nitrate (NO3) into nitrite (NO2). The Sulfur Indole Motility (SIM) assay uses Kovac’s reagent looks at three tests - sulfur reduction through cysteine desulfurase, indole production through tryptophanase, and motility. Simmons citrate agar assesses an organism’s ability to use citrate as a carbon source. The urea test determines whether an organism can break down urea that occurs due to the presence of the enzyme urease. Tests using litmus milk differentiate between bacterial species based on how they metabolize milk components. Using nutrient gelatin as a medium allows differentiation between organisms that make an exogenous enzyme named gelatinase and those that do not.

pageData.text: Bacteria that are able to break down lipids make an enzyme called lipase. <button class='glossary-text'>Spirit blue agar</button> is a medium that contains an exogenous lipid supply, typically corn oil. If lipase is present, the lipids will be digested. The medium is light blue due to the addition of a dye called spirit blue, which has the chemical formula C<sub class='bodysubscript'>37</sub>H<sub class='bodysubscript'>30</sub>CIN<sub class='bodysubscript'>3</sub>. Clearing of the dye, forming halos around the bacterial colonies, indicates positive lipase activity (Figure 20, sectors 25 and 4). Lipases are potentially commercially useful as remedies for cleaning up oil spills, and spirit blue <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> has been used as a screening method for some of those organisms.

pageData.disc: Figure 20: A Petri dish of blue colored spirit blue agar. The bottom of the dish is divided into 3 equal sections in ink marker. The first section, labeled 10, has microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second and third sections, labeled 25 and 4 respectively, each have microbial growth on the medium, surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the sites of growth. These two sections show positive results.
pageData.altText: Figure 20: A Petri dish of blue colored spirit blue agar. The bottom of the dish is divided into 3 equal sections in ink marker. The first section, labeled 10, has microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second and third sections, labeled 25 and 4 respectively, each have microbial growth on the medium, surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the sites of growth. These two sections show positive results.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>DNase agar</button> is used to check if an organism produces an exogenous enzyme called DNase (deoxyribonuclease) that can hydrolyze DNA. The <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> contains nutrients, DNA, and methyl green as an indicator. Methyl green is a cation that will bind to negatively charged DNA.
When the DNA is broken down, it will no longer bind to the methyl green and will produce a clear halo when DNase made by the organism is present (Figure 21, right).

pageData.disc: Figure 21: Two Petri dishes of blue-green DNase agar. The first dish shows microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second dish shows microbial growth on the medium surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the site of growth, which is a positive result.
pageData.altText: Figure 21: Two Petri dishes of blue-green DNase agar. The first dish shows microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second dish shows microbial growth on the medium surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the site of growth, which is a positive result.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Starch agar</button> tests for starch hydrolysis. Starch <button class='glossary-text'>media</button> contains beef extract, soluble starch, and <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button>. Starch is a large molecule that cannot be transported into a cell. If the bacteria secrete alpha amylase, it can degrade the starch by cleaving the glycosidic linkages of starch to produce individual glucose molecules. Iodine is the indicator used to detect starch hydrolysis. Iodine interacts with the chemical structure of starch and produces a blue/black color; if the starch is broken down, or hydrolyzed, the addition of iodine will result in a clear or yellow area on the medium (Figure 22, right).

pageData.disc: Figure 22: Six Petri dishes of starch agar. The first three dishes show bacterial growth before iodine is added to the plates. The second three dishes are the first three dishes after iodine is added to the plates, the media in which appear blue-black. Of the after-iodine plates, two plates are cleared of the dark color at and around the sites of bacterial growth on the media, which is a positive result. The third after-iodine plate has little to no color change at or around the site of bacterial growth on the medium, which is a negative result.
pageData.altText: Figure 22: Six Petri dishes of starch agar. The first three dishes show bacterial growth before iodine is added to the plates. The second three dishes are the first three dishes after iodine is added to the plates, the media in which appear blue-black. Of the after-iodine plates, two plates are cleared of the dark color at and around the sites of bacterial growth on the media, which is a positive result. The third after-iodine plate has little to no color change at or around the site of bacterial growth on the medium, which is a negative result.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Blood agar</button> is a growth medium made of tryptic soy <button class='glossary-text'>agar</button> that is enriched with 5% sheep’s blood. Bood agar is primarily used to determine whether bacteria can perform <button class='glossary-text'>hemolysis</button>. Hemolysis is the ability of a bacterial cell to lyse red blood cells. Lysis will cause partial or complete destruction of the red blood cells in the blood agar plates.

There are three major types of hemolysis that can be observed:
  • Alpha hemolysis: partial lysis of red blood cells that produces a greenish or brownish discoloration (Figure 23, left). The greenish color is a result of the breakdown of hemoglobin, resulting in the byproduct biliverdin.
  • Beta hemolysis: complete lysis of red blood cells that causes a clearing of the blood from the near the bacterial (Figure 23, middle). This is due to the production of hemolysins that break down red blood cells and hemoglobin completely.
  • Gamma hemolysis: no hemolysis of red blood cells and no change in the media surrounding the bacterial colonies (Figure 23, right). This indicates that the organism is non-hemolytic.

pageData.disc: Figure 23: Three Petri dishes of blood agar medium with bacterial growth. The first plate is labeled alpha and shows bacterial growth with brownish discoloration. The second plate is labeled beta and shows bacterial growth with clearing of the blood from the medium at and around the site of growth. The third plate is labeled gamma and shows bacterial growth with no change in the media at or around the site of growth.
pageData.altText: Figure 23: Three Petri dishes of blood agar medium with bacterial growth. The first plate is labeled alpha and shows bacterial growth with brownish discoloration. The second plate is labeled beta and shows bacterial growth with clearing of the blood from the medium at and around the site of growth. The third plate is labeled gamma and shows bacterial growth with no change in the media at or around the site of growth.

pageData.text: Catalase is an enzyme used to degrade hydrogen peroxide, which is bactericidal and is generally found in aerobic organisms. Hydrogen peroxide is a common byproduct of metabolic pathways. Catalase works by enhancing the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide into oxygen gas and water. This is a very common test to differentiate between groups of bacteria. Many bacteria are catalase-positive, but two common groups that are catalase-negative are Streptococcus and Enterococcus.

Using the slide method, an overnight culture of bacteria is grown. A small amount of bacteria is transferred to a dry glass slide using sterile technique. A drop of 3% hydrogen peroxide is added to the bacteria and mixed. The slide is observed for 30 seconds: if bubbles form, oxygen gas has formed and the organism is catalase-positive (Figure 24, top), while the absence of bubbles indicates the organism is catalase-negative (Figure 24, bottom).

pageData.disc: Figure 24: Two glass microscope slides each with catalase test results. The first slide has a small pool of clear liquid filled with foamy bubbles, which is a positive result. The second slide has a small pool of clear liquid with no bubbles, which is a negative result.
pageData.altText: Figure 24: Two glass microscope slides each with catalase test results. The first slide has a small pool of clear liquid filled with foamy bubbles, which is a positive result. The second slide has a small pool of clear liquid with no bubbles, which is a negative result.

pageData.text: The is used to determine if bacteria make cytochrome c oxidase. This enzyme is present in the electron transport chain of some bacteria. All bacteria that are oxidase-positive are aerobic and use oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor in cellular respiration. Bacteria that are negative can be aerobic, anaerobic, or facultatively anaerobic, and may have other oxidases besides cytochrome c present in electron transport.

This test must be done quickly as the reagents will start to oxidize with the air, which can result in a false positive reading. Readings should be taken 10 to 30 seconds after the addition of reagent and any color change after 30 seconds should be considered a false positive.

An oxidase-positive result is a dark purple or maroon color change within 30 seconds (Figure 25 left); an oxidase-negative result is white or no color change before 30 seconds (Figure 25 right). In this test, a small amount of culture is put on a sterile piece of paper. Oxidase reagent is then added, which contains a molecule that changes color when reduced.

pageData.disc: Figure 25: Two sheets of paper showing two different oxidase test results. The first sheet of paper is wet in the center with an immediate color change in the center of the wet spot, which is a positive result. The second sheet of paper is wet with no color change, which is a negative result. The negative result is labeled with "If color change appears after 30 seconds that is a false positive."
pageData.altText: Figure 25: Two sheets of paper showing two different oxidase test results. The first sheet of paper is wet in the center with an immediate color change in the center of the wet spot, which is a positive result. The second sheet of paper is wet with no color change, which is a negative result. The negative result is labeled with "If color change appears after 30 seconds that is a false positive."

Does the microbe metabolize lactose?
  1. Yes... The unknown microbe is Escherichia coli.
  2. No... The unknown microbe is Salmonella enteritidis.

pageData.content: Figure 1. Three types of bacterial growth media
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Examples of broth, plate, and semi-solid bacterial growth media.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Surface bacterial growth
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A tube of broth medium, on the surface of which is bacterial growth.

pageData.content: Figure 3. Streak plate examples
pageData.altText: Figure 3: 4 different streak plates. Each plate has bacterial colonies with a different shape and color.

pageData.content: Figure 4. Biochemical broth tube test examples
pageData.altText: Figure 4: 4 different biochemical tests performed in inoculated broth tubes - pH, urea, indole and glucose - next to a control tube with 24 hour growth.

pageData.content: Figure 5. Bacteria morphologies and arrangements
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Examples of spherical, rod, and curved shapes of bacteria

pageData.content: Figure 6. Gram-negative and Gram-positive cell walls
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Differences in peptidoglycan in Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.content: Figure 7. Gram stain workflow
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Steps in the Gram-staining technique

pageData.content: Figure 8. Example of Gram staining
pageData.altText: Figure 8: A differential stain distinguishes Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria

pageData.content: Figure 9. Example of capsule staining
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Micrograph of several stained rod-shaped bacterial cells, each surrounded by a clear colorless halo representing a capsule. One capsule is indicated with an arrow.

pageData.content: Figure 10. Example of endospore staining
pageData.altText: Figure 10: An illustration and a micrograph showing stained vegetative cells and endospores. Each image shows rod-shaped vegetative cells and circular endospores.

pageData.content: Figure 11. Example of acid-fast staining
pageData.altText: Figure 11: A micrograph of two different bacteria species stained with acid-fast staining. One type of bacteria, labeled A, are circular and purple. The other type of bacteria, labeled B, are rod shaped and pink.

pageData.content: Figure 12. Phenol red fermentation negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 12: A negative control phenol red broth tube on the left, and a positive control phenol red broth tube on the right. Each tube has a small upside down Durham tube placed at the bottom of the tube. The negative control has red broth with no bubbles inside its Durham tube. The positive control has yellow broth, which indicates carbohydrate source metabolism, and a gas bubble captured inside its Durham tube.

pageData.content: Figure 13. MRVP negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Five different inoculated MRVP broth tubes. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second tube shows a positive result after the addition of methyl red as a sustained red color. The third tube shows a negative result after the addition of methyl red as a yellow color change. The fourth tube shows a positive result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a red color. The fifth tube shows a negative result after the addition of Voges-Proskauer reagents as a copper color change.

pageData.content: Figure 14. Nitrate reduction test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 14: Six different inoculated broth tubes demonstrating nitrate reduction test results. The first tube shows bacterial growth in the broth without any reagents. The second and third tubes show positive results as red and pink color changes, respectively. The fourth tube shows an inconclusive result as a yellow color change. The fifth tube shows a negative result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as no color change. The sixth tube shows a positive result after zinc was added to an inconclusive result as a red color change.

pageData.content: Figure 15. SIM agar test positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 15: Three test tubes of sulfur indole motility agar inoculated with bacteria. The first tube has a precipitate in the bottom. The second tube has a thin top layer that changed color after Kovac's reagent was added. The third tube has cloudiness away from the central stab of the inoculating needle.

pageData.content: Figure 16. Simmons citrate agar test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 16: Two culture tubes containing inoculated slants of solid simmons citrate agar. The first tube shows a negative result with green medium. The second tube shows a positive result with blue medium.

pageData.content: Figure 17. Urea test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 17: Two test tubes filled with inoculated broth media containing a pH indicator and urea. The first tube shows a negative result with a light orange color change. The second tube shows a positive result with a magenta pink color change.

pageData.content: Figure 18. Examples of litmus milk results
pageData.altText: Figure 18: Seven culture tubes containing litmus milk media. The first tube is uninoculated and has a milky pink color. The six other culture tubes are inoculated and show various color changes after 7 days of incubation.

pageData.content: Figure 19. Nutrient gelatin test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 19: Two culture tubes containing inoculated semi-solid media. The first tube shows a negative result with unmoving semi-solid media. The second tube shows a positive result with moving, liquified semi-solid media.

pageData.content: Figure 20. Spirit blue agar test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 20: A Petri dish of blue colored spirit blue agar. The bottom of the dish is divided into 3 equal sections in ink marker. The first section, labeled 10, has microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second and third sections, labeled 25 and 4 respectively, each have microbial growth on the medium, surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the sites of growth. These two sections show positive results.

pageData.content: Figure 21. DNase agar test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 21: Two Petri dishes of blue-green DNase agar. The first dish shows microbial growth on the medium, which is a negative result. The second dish shows microbial growth on the medium surrounded by a clearing of color at and around the site of growth, which is a positive result.

pageData.content: Figure 22. Starch agar test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 22: Six Petri dishes of starch agar. The first three dishes show bacterial growth before iodine is added to the plates. The second three dishes are the first three dishes after iodine is added to the plates, the media in which appear blue-black. Of the after-iodine plates, two plates are cleared of the dark color at and around the sites of bacterial growth on the media, which is a positive result. The third after-iodine plate has little to no color change at or around the site of bacterial growth on the medium, which is a negative result.

pageData.content: Figure 23. Three types of hemolysis on blood agar plates
pageData.altText: Figure 23: Three Petri dishes of blood agar medium with bacterial growth. The first plate is labeled alpha and shows bacterial growth with brownish discoloration. The second plate is labeled beta and shows bacterial growth with clearing of the blood from the medium at and around the site of growth. The third plate is labeled gamma and shows bacterial growth with no change in the media at or around the site of growth.

pageData.content: Figure 24. Catalase test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 24: Two glass microscope slides each with catalase test results. The first slide has a small pool of clear liquid filled with foamy bubbles, which is a positive result. The second slide has a small pool of clear liquid with no bubbles, which is a negative result.

pageData.content: Figure 25. Oxidase test negative and positive controls
pageData.altText: Figure 25: Two sheets of paper showing two different oxidase test results. The first sheet of paper is wet in the center with an immediate color change in the center of the wet spot, which is a positive result. The second sheet of paper is wet with no color change, which is a negative result. The negative result is labeled with "If color change appears after 30 seconds that is a false positive."

pageData.content: Dichotomous_Key

data.title: Acid-fast stain
data.content: A type of differential staining technique used to distinguish members of the genera Mycobacterium and Nocardia from most other bacteria

data.title: Agar
data.content: A jelly-like substance to which nutrients can be added to serve as a general-purpose medium for bacteria and other cells

data.title: Bacillus
data.content: Rod-shaped bacterium; plural, bacilli

data.title: Blood agar
data.content: A solid plate medium comprised of 5% blood used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce hemolysins and break down red blood cells and hemoglobin

data.title: Broth tube
data.content: A liquid nutrient medium used to culture microbes

data.title: Capsule
data.content: The smooth, round, outermost layer of a bacterial cell; this layer is called the slime layer when it is an irregular shape

data.title: Catalase test
data.content: A biochemical assay used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce catalase enzyme and break down hydrogen peroxide

data.title: Coccus
data.content: Spherical bacterium; plural, cocci

data.title: Colony
data.content: An aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells

data.title: Dichotomous key
data.content: A system of identifying items based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptions

data.title: Direct stain
data.content: A type of simple stain in which the dye interacts with the bacteria themselves

data.title: DNase agar
data.content: A solid plate medium used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce DNase enzyme and hydrolyze DNA

data.title: Durham tube
data.content: A small test tube inverted and placed within a broth tube for the purpose of collecting any gas produced by a bacteria culture

data.title: Endospore
data.content: Metabolically inactive, highly resistant structures produced by certain bacteria to enable survival under harsh conditions

data.title: Fixing
data.content: Adhering bacteria to a microscope slide

data.title: Gram stain
data.content: A differential staining technique that stains bacteria differently based on the peptidoglycan composition of their cell walls

data.title: Hemolysis
data.content: The ability of a bacterial cell to lyse red blood cells

data.title: Inoculation
data.content: The process of introducing microbes (referring to a culture medium)

data.title: Litmus milk
data.content: A liquid medium of milk and litmus pH indicator used to perform milk metabolism assays

data.title: Media
data.content: Substances used to support microbial growth; singular, medium

data.title: Mordant
data.content: A substance that fixes a dye or stain in a material when the two are combined

data.title: Morphology
data.content: The shape or structure of an organism

data.title: Motility
data.content: The ability of an organism to propel itself

data.title: MR-VP broth
data.content: A broth medium used to perform metabolic assays on bacteria using methyl red pH indicator and Voges-Proskauer reagents; stands for Methyl Red Voges-Proskauer

data.title: Negative stain
data.content: A staining technique that uses an acidic dye to stain the background of a slide rather than the bacteria directly

data.title: Nitrate reduction test
data.content: A biochemical assay used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce nitrate reductase enzyme

data.title: Nutrient gelatin
data.content: A semi-solid medium used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce gelatinase enzyme and metabolize gelatin

data.title: Obligate
data.content: Describes an organism that requires a specific resource or nutrient to survive

data.title: Oxidase test
data.content: A biochemical assay used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce cytochrome c oxidase enzyme

data.title: Pathogen
data.content: A microbe that causes disease

data.title: Semi-solid
data.content: Gelatinous; describes some types of nutrient media used to culture microbes

data.title: SIM agar
data.content: A semi-solid medium used to perform amino acid metabolism and motility assays on bacteria; stands for sulfur indole motility

data.title: Simmons citrate agar
data.content: A solid tube medium used to perform citrate metabolism assays

data.title: Simple stain
data.content: A technique for visualizing bacteria cells by making certain structures visible under a microscope

data.title: Spirillum
data.content: Rigid, spiral-shaped bacteria; plural, spirilla

data.title: Spirit blue agar
data.content: A solid plate medium used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce lipase and metabolize lipids

data.title: Starch agar
data.content: A solid plate medium used to determine a bacteria culture's ability to produce alpha amylase enzyme and metabolize starch

data.title: Streak plate
data.content: A common microbiological technique used to isolate pure cultures from a mixed culture

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Cloudiness in a solution that is a result of small particles in suspension

data.title: Urea
data.content: An end byproduct of amino acid metabolism

data.title: Virulence factor
data.content: A characteristic of a pathogen that enhances its ability to cause disease by protecting it from immune responses
